children.subject:
It is based on the semester in which the class will occur.

So if you are a junior in Fall 20 you will not qualify for the reserved seating. We recommend adding an unpopular lab (early morning or late Friday) during your Phase 1. We are also offering 16AB remotely over summer so that is another option. Email me if you want to discuss your options in detail.

For reserved seats, are schools years (freshman, sophomore, etc) based on this current semester or your status in the semester that the class will occur? For instance, I am currently a 2nd semester sophomore, so if I enroll in a class that has priority for LSCS sophomores but not juniors, am I considered a sophomore or a junior?
You can enroll in any lab with open seats and you will need to enroll in DIS 999 for 16AB.
Can I enroll in any discussion or lab section that is not 999?
It will be offered: https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2020-fall-data-c100-001-lec-001
is Data100 offered for fall2020? I can't find it under STATS or COMPSCI
* sorry 50 seats on classes.berkeley.edu and 120 seats on Calcentral
I would save this question until CS info comes out
What is CS info? And why did you mark this unresolved? My question is still unanswered

If you notice, this post is for EE/EECS class enrollment information for Fall 2020, likely there will be a similar post for CS class enrollment for Fall 2020, and that would be an appropriate place to ask this question
Thank you, you didn’t have to be rude though!

My apologies, my intentions were not to come across as rude, but I see how short answers can seem that way, especially when text is used as communication instead of face to face. Best of luck getting into CS 160.
Thank you for the help, and thank you for clarifying!
Is there a reason why there is no waitlist for CS160? There's 50 seats on CalCentral but 120 Seats on classes.berkeley.edu, but 0 seats for the waitlist.

I want to add onto this. Since I will be a 4th year in Fall 2020, I'm not guaranteed to enroll into 16b, a *requirement* I must fulfill. So then I must try my luck for Spring 2021 and hope I enroll in 16B? It worries me that I'm not certain in enrolling in this required class.
What are reasons/steps to acquire "Enrollment Permission" so I may guarantee my enrollment in this class that's a *requirement*?
Thank you!

You will automatically be placed on the waitlist. The reserved seating will be the same for future semesters. We recommend still adding the class during Phase 1 and choosing an unpopular lab (early morning or Fridays are usually the least popular).Historically it is easier to get into 16B in the Fall (last Fall the class did not fill up) than the Spring so we recommend adding it for the Fall.  

We do not issue enrollment permission codes to enroll in the class. Enrollment permissions seats are reserved for CS Scholars (we have no other way of coding this in the system.)

If you have further questions, email me.

So if I’m going to be a senior in Fall 2020, if I attempt to enroll in EE 16B, does that mean I will automatically be placed on the waitlist for lecture/the lab that I choose to enroll in, even if there are some open seats at the time I attempted to enroll? Also, have the enrollment priorities/reserved seating arrangements for EE 16B for Spring 2021 been decided yet, or that is yet to be determined? Thanks so much!
Also, if it's being offered, what's the expected time slot?
Not being offered in F20 but is in the draft schedule for Sp21.

Is 219A being offered this semester? It shows up on the catalog but isn't in the EE draft schedule.

If so, who's teaching it? The professor who usually teaches it is teaching 120 next semester.
From Data 001 Piazza: https://piazza.com/class/j7s01y165odq5?cid=2460
Why is CS C100 closed in Fall 2020? Will it be open?
Got in. loool
Do junior EECS majors have any enrollment priority? Like, am I guaranteed to get into CS162 and CS161?
Not likely since the class is not formally approved to have a no lab option.
In the past there has been a "no lab" option for EE16B, Would this possibly be the case next semester?
You do need to enroll in DIS 999 but all students have already been moved to DIS999 without losing their waitlist position. Email me if you have questions on this.
I enrolled in EECS16A and chose an actual discussion section (i.e at a certain time). Do I need to enroll in DIS 999?
I had the same question
I was told that Spring normally has a much larger enrollment capacity because freshman often take 16B in the Spring. Hope that helps!

That is correct, Spring is usually larger than Fall because new students take 16A in the Fall and then 16B in the Spring to finish these courses in their first year. 
Fall 2020 currently has a capacity of 300 since last fall we had ~270 enrolled in 16B. 
It is easier to get into 16B in the Fall semester instead of Spring.

Hi! With regards to EE 16B, I know that the post says "At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post when we have more information.", but I was just curious as to if anyone knows why 16B has a capacity of 1044 for Spring 2020 but Fall 2020 only has a capacity of 300 (and is unlikely to expand, according to the post). Is the enrollment capacity normally much larger in the Spring than Fall for 16B, so Spring 2021 will probably have a much larger capacity than Fall 2020? Thanks so much!

leaving this unresolved so an instructor can chime in, but for example if there is still shelter in place by the time fall semester comes around, or a second wave of coronavirus hits open campus in fall (like with the spanish flu) that could cause online courses.

We don't know what COVID-19 situation will look like by then. It could be possible but we don't have any information about that and are proceeding with the expectation that in person instruction will resume in the fall.
As today, is there any possibility that some or even all EE/CS Fall20 courses could potentially be moved to online?

Check Berkeleytime for historical enrollment data. Sanders and Lustig are both pretty popular, so it might be tougher to get into than usual.

16B is a freshman class. The whole point of their enrollment rules is to give you an incentive to take it ASAP. How is this policy backwards if you've had 6 chances to phase 1 the class starting freshman spring (transfer seniors have reserved seats) and have burned through all of the chances you had at a reserved spot?

EE16b is personally the least useful in my projected future so I chose to take it latest as possible. Obviously I'm not the only person that thinks this because many seniors end up taking this class their senior year. I don't think a required class for graduation that is not a major-declaration and is not a core cs class should incentivize taking it their first two years, especially since those first two years should be used to learn as much as possible to get ready to intern at companies like google, amazon, etc. (I'm curious how taking ee16b as a freshmen helped you in the industry). What's backwards is that a non-core cs class that is basic linear algebra + ee, (which ee will be never touched by most of cs grads pursuing swe), is incentivized to be taken their first two years. The main idea is either make up your mind and give full autonomy in changing around schedule so you can take a class when you want to by giving priority toward graduation as every other class is done or make it strict by making it required within first x years to strictly enforce taking it if they really believe it's important

I think this is a popular sentiment, but there's a reason that they changed the course title to EECS 16B.

16B I think is the most misrepresented class on campus (full disclosure I've been on the course staff before). It's basic circuit theory and engineering mathematical analysis. You don't EE that would be completely useless to a CS major, like designing a power grid. If they made 16B about power systems and semiconductor fabrication, I would understand all the screaming and shouting. However, that's absolutely not what the class is about.

It's a common misconception that 16B and math 54 overlap. The two share nothing aside from a little bit of differential equations. 16A is the "54 equivalent". Most of the engineering analysis topics in 16B are nontrivially rooted in linear algebra (SVD, PCA, spectral theorem, control/reachability analysis) and are sufficiently novel to be worth a separate class, even for someone who has taken 54. A lot of these ideas actually come back in machine learning, which is definitely relevant to CS majors. Sure, if you take a class like 127 first, but the entire point is that 16B is supposed to prepare you for 127.

Signal processing is also an important part of the class. CV has tons of this stuff where you deal with sampling/aliasing and the ramifications of discretized frequencies. Surely computer vision is CS right?

Even the circuit part ties in nicely to CS as well. Most people in CS don't work on hardware, but 61C is really really surface-level it teaches you about hardware concepts like power consumption and frequency. It's just hand-wavy electron magic that somehow is 0 or 1. In 16B, you learn how current flow through computer chips actually works and what kind of limitations they face. Sure it's niche, but I still think this is within the realm of what a CS major should teach you. We're lucky we don't have a requirement for a full-blown digital systems class like they do at UCSD and UCLA.

Sure, I wasnt saying its a useless class by any means. I'm fully aware that those things that you mentioned are relevant for ml. I don't think the helping prepare for 127 is enough to justify it as a required course, but that's not the point I'm making. If you want to do ml, which a lot of people dont, you don't need to take 127, you can take 189, etc etc, and they dont require 16b as a prereq. I do deep learning at a fang and I dont regret not taking ee16b, nor do I think I'll need to take ee16b given that there are plenty of other classes that cover similar content. I can agree that sure there are some topics that can 'tie nicely into cs', but thats just about every cs class, and its also not my point. Back to my point, I'm simply saying either make up your mind and give full autonomy in changing around schedule so you can take a class when you want to by giving priority toward graduation as every other class is done or make it strict by making it required within first x years to strictly enforce taking it if they really believe it's important. Perhaps the department has their reasons, but I think giving priority to student graduation is pretty important, i.e expand senior reservation or some other alternative that can balance things out. It's not that I dont want to take the class, its just that Id like to have a reasonable chance at taking the class as a senior so I can graduate. Although I'm sure Im overreacting and the waitlist will go down and I can take the class haha

As a lower-division class, we need to give priority to 1st/2nd years. Not qualifying for the reserved seats does not mean you will not be enrolled in the class. This just means you may not get into your first choice of lab. 
The good news is that the fall semester has less demand than Spring. Last fall, there were only 271 students enrolled and the most students we have seen in a fall semester was 346. I can't say that will be the case this fall nor can I guarantee that the class will be expanded at this time. You will just need to be patient and stay on the waitlist until the reserved seats expire. Email me if you have further questions.
Additionally the point of an EECS education is not to prepare you for a job at Amazon or Google.
It is for some people, no?
That might be their objective i.e. what they hope to get out of it but that's certainly not what a university's purpose is or what they should plan enrollment around.

Student Learning Goals

Mission

  1. Preparing graduates to pursue postgraduate education in electrical engineering, computer science, or related fields.
  2. Preparing graduates for success in technical careers related to electrical and computer engineering, or computer science and engineering.
  3. Preparing graduates to become leaders in fields related to electrical and computer engineering or computer science and engineering.

http://guide.berkeley.edu/undergraduate/degree-programs/electrical-engineering-computer-sciences/#studentlearninggoalstext 

Seems like an explicit learning goal.
@Anonymous Scale Out of curiosity what is your objective in going through university and why do you pay between 100 to 250k for it?
Oops I meant @Anonymous Gear

Sorry, I definitely misspoke when I said "job" when I should have said "internship." A cs/engineering degree definitely should prepare you well for an industry role of your choosing but notice that does say graduates. "Prepare graduates for success in technical careers" =/= "those first two years should be used to learn as much as possible to get ready to intern at companies like google, amazon, etc" which sounds way too much like a university-sanctioned hypercompetitive rat race to me when the resume chasing culture is already as bad as it is. I'm not saying that wanting to intern wherever is a bad goal—it's one of my goals—but rather that the onus is on students. I do agree though that 16a/b should just be made mandatory rather than incentivized because it's part of a well rounded ee/cs education. Not trying to come off as self righteous here, but hastily typed text answers certainly tend to have that effect :(

I honestly think CS should be its own major at Berkeley. Some people are just not interested in EE at all and making EE16A/B a requirement for those in l&s is totally unfair. We should have a separate major in Electrical Engineering offered within CoE and a separate major, B.S in Computer Science in l&s. Students interested in both areas should instead take electives in their areas of interest. (EECS major stressing about finals). Go bears!

This is ridiculous. At a school like UCSD (which has a dedicated program) for example, if you do CSE, you're forced to take the equivalent of 151 + 152 in order to graduate. You guys need to stop complaining since I would much rather take 2 semesters of lower div electrical engineering than 2 semesters of advanced digital design and architecture to graduate.

You can't have your cake and eat it two. Any CS major is going to have low-level requirements. Just suck it up.

And in reality, it's only 1 electrical engineering class. If you summed EE 16AB together and broke it down, it would be one semester of linear algebra/DE and one semester EE (circuits/controls/signal processing). It's just ordered weirdly.

Any program that doesn't make CS majors take LA/DE is going to be a joke, so you're really complaining about one semester of electrical engineering when your peers at UCSD have to learn how to design an entire five staged pipelined CPU in Verilog.
LA/DE can be learnt without having to take EE16A/B. There are math classes that teach that.
I agree with the above comment: that LA/DE can be learnt from taking Math classes. Actually, designing a five stage pipeline CPU is well within the realm of CS. I'd rather take a class on that tbh.

But having EE16A/B being the required way to take LA/DE isn't unreasonable. Plenty of schools make engineering students take applied math courses labeled under engineering. Ours just happens to be labeled EE. Big deal.

Digital design requires knowing a thing or two about E&M (resistance and power). Guess where you're learning that? Not 61C for sure. At UCSD their CS majors take physics too, so they don't need to enforce a basic circuits requirement. But 151 enforces 16B. So EE 16B would end up one of those classes that isn't a major prereq, but is a prereq for a major prereq. At UCSD they have classes like that. Thank goodness we don't.

All in all you guys are just complaining about one semester worth of EE content when in reality most schools are much much worse about requirements. Most schools' CS majors aren't designed to be finishable in 2.5 years at 3 techs a semester.

You're also not supposed to be taking 54 as CS major. You guys are treating the alternative option like it should be the officially supported one. Math 54:16A::Math55:70. The CS curriculum is designed around EE16AB, much like it is around 70.

The department only really keeps 54 around as an option for transfers or double majors so they don't get completely flooded in terms of graduation requirements. But for most of you who are single CS major freshman admits, you shouldn't be in that class in the first place.

But it seems that giving students an alternative option just causes entitlement and the idea that the original requirement is stupid and should be done away with entirely. Maybe they should just force EE 16AB so people don't take 54 and get "surprised" that 16B is a thing and complain about taking it as a senior. I bet if the only way you could learn about linear algebra is 16AB, you would take that class real quick because you want to do machine learning

I am a more EE person, so maybe sharing my perspective helps. I guess the impression that eecs16a/b are EE classes comes from the fact that they were called ee16a/b. However, after taking upper div EE courses, you will quickly realize that 16a/b contain very little EE. For example, there are no devices physics, electrodynamics, photonics, or MEMS in 16a/b, which require students to know physics, chemistry, and math at a level much higher than that of 16a/b. Some EE students are taking ee105 and 120 before taking 16b simply because 16b has become more and more CS-oriented and. Having circuit in a class doesn’t make it a hardcore EE class and not many EE upper divs are about circuit design. Most of the knowledge you learn from 16a/b are things like control and signal processing, which directly connects to CS topics nowadays. Honestly, fields such as control and signal processing are in the intersection of CS, EE, ME, etc, and its very hard to classify whether you are learning CS or EE; therefore, the sentiment that we should not study any EE is kind of shortsighted. Moreover, if you really doesn’t want touch any EE, why do a lot of CS students take EECS126/127/106a/149/225b? These were all ee courses originally, but the majority of the enrollment comes from the CS major. So why should you treat 16a/b differently? From the EE perspective, all of the EECS courses are created to better accommodate the CS students. Although they are all EE courses in the old days, the content and application has evolved so much that they should no longer be named under EE.

I am a senior and I'd like to graduate so I phase 1'd EE16b as fast as possible and still got waitlisted at position 182. What's the likelihood of enrolling into the class and are there possible expansions? Also what is the idea behind not giving seniors priority?

This seems backwards given students must take 16b but have less priority in enrolling in the class as you get closer to graduation.

I am also seeing an enrollment error for EE 16B. The message looks like this:

Request not processed. There is no wait list available. The wait list request was not processed, as there are no wait list places available for one or more of the class sections in this request.

Can someone clarify why this happened?
Check the lab you were trying to add yourself to. Some labs already have a full waitlist so you will need to choose another one.

I did check the lab, but as far as I can tell there are still seats available. 

This is what happens when I try to enroll.
Is there any follow up on this issue? I am having the same problem
Lab 109 has a full waitlist so you will need to choose another lab. See the current waitlist and enrollment info here : https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2020-fall-eecs-16b-001-lec-001

Error: Request not processed. There is no wait list available. The wait list request was not processed, as there are no wait list places available for one or more of the class sections in this request.


giving me this currently? I assume the waitlist will be reopened phase 2/?
Can we expect eecs 126 to increase capacity to match previous semesters numbers come phase 2?
The class was already expanded to 500. At this time, we have no plans to expand it further.

Could EECS 16B be expanded since the amount of waitlist is getting larger and larger, and there are plenty of students want to take and need to take it for declaring major due to the grading situation of CS 70 for this semester?

We have updated the language to avoid this confusion. At this time, if you do not qualify for the reserved seating you will be put on the waitlist and will have to wait until the adjustment period to enroll. Email me if you have any additional concerns and I'd be happy to discuss your enrollment.

I am currently a Freshman MechE student waitlisted for EECS 16B for my Sophomore fall semester. Looking at the "Getting into EE Classes" guide, it seems to say that all first-years and Fall sophomores may enroll directly in the class, but I was put directly on the waitlist (#282). Is this because I am not currently an EECS student? Also, I am transferring majors to EECS as soon as I receive grades for this semester. Will this have any effect on my enrollment? It seems like at least Fall sophomore EECS should be able to get straight in since I enrolled Phase 1. Thank you for the help!

Is there a way to see my position on the waitlist for the lab section that I'm enrolled in? I can see my overall waitlist position (in the 140s), but I'd like to be able to see my waitlist position w.r.t the other students who are trying to enroll in the same lab as mine.
(everything with regards to 16B* that is)

it has recently expanded to 580. Even though everything is remote, expanding the class further depends on the availability to hire additional course staff and supply more lab kits. I am still looking into whether or not we can expand the class further.
Will 16B expand beyond 500 seats given that everything is going to be remote?

There are 60 seats reserved for undeclared sophomore students (see "Reserved Seats" section), but all those seats seem to be already taken. I wouldn't worry too much about it; you've joined the waitlist early and historically, everyone has been able to enroll into the course.

Hi, I'm an incoming sophomore undeclared in L&S. I tried enrolling in EECS16A as part of my Phase1.5; I enrolled in lecture, DIS999, and LAB110, all of which have availability and open seating -- but I've still been waitlisted.

EECS16A doesn't seem to have reserved seats for undeclared L&S, but after checking out the lower division section of "Getting into CS Classes" (since, by my understanding, ECS16A is a lower div CS requirement) I am still confused: undeclared L&S first- and second-years clearly have reservations in Phase1. (https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy#lower) 

What should I do? Is this anything to worry about?
I'm pretty worried about this, as I'm a senior and need all these courses for graduation, so any help is appreciated!

16A isn't allowing time conflicts which could be why you have not been able to enroll in your poli sci class. Email me at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu with your SID so that I can look into this for you.

"Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes"

I am enrolled in cs170. I'm on the waitlist for eecs16a and polisci124a. These classes all have time conflicts. But polisci124a doesn't conflict with any other of my courses.

I got a notice that I couldn't be enrolled into polisci124a off of the waitlist because of time conflicts. How is this possible, when the only classes it conflicts with are eecs courses?

You were likely placed on the waitlist because you do not qualify for the reserved seats at this time. 

Depends on what lab you chose. Most 8am or Friday labs are unpopular so they may not fill up. 

There is plenty of space to enroll everyone off the waitlist at this time so I would't worry about it too much.

Email me at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you have additional questions.

I am currently on the waitlist for EECS16A, and the Lab section I'm trying to enroll in has a 55-seat maximum with 35 open seats. However, I've ben placed 8th on that section's waitlist -- I assume this is because I'm on the waitlist for the lecture (at position 82). 

Questions: 

- should I worry about my Lab filling up -- and thus me not being able to enroll in EECS16A? 

- should I worry about not being able to get into the lecture? 

Thanks!

Thanks for this! The lecture seats were expanded but not the discussion (just did that now) so you should see an update in your enrollment status the next time the waitlist automatically processes, 6:40pm.
I was currently waitlisted by EE130; however, classes .berkeley.edu shows that there is still 9 available seats. Is this a bug?

history.content:
Fall 2020 EE and EECS enrollment information:

Enrollment Priorities for EECS 16A and EECS16B can be found on classes.berkeley.edu. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post when we have more information.

  • If either one of these classes are required for you to graduate, we recommend you use Phase 1. Note that there will be no reserved seats for juniors and seniors. 

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

EE and EECS upper-division classes: These classes still do not have enrollment priorities. 

999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EECS16AB will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For 16AB, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted:  If you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections. Please reach out to the enrollment manager for assistance, we do not want you to accidentally drop a class or be added onto the watilist if you were already enrolled,

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes (EECS 16A, 127/227AT are not allowing time conflicts). It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates. Time conflicts are only enabled for lectures, not discussions/labs.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment drop-in hours will be by appointment only. Schedule an appointment at youcanbookme. For questions email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.
history.subject: EE/EECS Fall 2020 Enrollment Information

history.content:

Enrollment Priorities for EECS 16A and EECS16B can be found on classes.berkeley.edu. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post when we have more information.

  • If either one of these classes are required for you to graduate, we recommend you use Phase 1. Note that there will be no reserved seats for juniors and seniors. 

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted:  If you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections. Please reach out to the enrollment manager for assistance, we do not want you to accidentally drop a class or be added onto the watilist if you were already enrolled,

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes (EECS 16A, 127/227AT are not allowing time conflicts). It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates. Time conflicts are only enabled for lectures, not discussions/labs.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment drop-in hours will be by appointment only. Schedule an appointment at youcanbookme. For questions email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

#pin

Fall 2020 EE and EECS enrollment information:

Enrollment Priorities for EECS 16A and EECS16B can be found on classes.berkeley.edu. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post when we have more information.

  • If either one of these classes are required for you to graduate, we recommend you use Phase 1. Note that there will be no reserved seats for juniors and seniors. 

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

EE and EECS upper-division classes: These classes still do not have enrollment priorities. 

999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EECS16AB will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For 16AB, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted:  If you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections. Please reach out to the enrollment manager for assistance, we do not want you to accidentally drop a class or be added onto the watilist if you were already enrolled,

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes (EECS 16A, 127/227AT are not allowing time conflicts). It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates. Time conflicts are only enabled for lectures, not discussions/labs.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment drop-in hours will be by appointment only. Schedule an appointment at youcanbookme. For questions email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

#pin
history.subject: EE/EECS Fall 2020 Enrollment Information

history.content:
Fall 2020 EE and EECS enrollment information:

Enrollment Priorities for EECS 16A and EECS16B can be found on classes.berkeley.edu. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post when we have more information.

  • If either one of these classes are required for you to graduate, we recommend you use Phase 1. Note that there will be no reserved seats for juniors and seniors. 

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

EE and EECS upper-division classes: These classes still do not have enrollment priorities. 

999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EECS16AB will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For 16AB, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted:  If you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections. Please reach out to the enrollment manager for assistance, we do not want you to accidentally drop a class or be added onto the watilist if you were already enrolled,

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates. Time conflicts are only enabled for lectures, not discussions/labs.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment drop-in hours will be by appointment only. Schedule an appointment at youcanbookme. For questions email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.
